As many of you know, Heather, our wonderful Marketing & Comms Officer, recently received the devastating news that she has been diagnosed with bowel cancer that has spread to her liver.  She is currently undergoing a course of palliative chemotherapy at the Western.

As those of you who know Heather well will know, she is a very private person who hates any 'fuss', so she has specifically asked that we don't send her flowers/presents/cards etc.  She is however happy for us to set-up a just giving page for MacMillan Care Care, who provided amazing care for her sister who recently died of lung cancer.

story:
• Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page❤️
  • My grandad Frank William Bagley passed away in hospital 2018 when he lost his fight to Stage 4 Non Hodgkin Lymphoma cancer which spread throughout his body. After endless amounts of chemotherapy and Radiotherapy his body did not react the way we hoped. Frank was a family man and was as deep as the ocean. He loved his crosswords and cowboy films, he loved socialising in his local club in Southwick and had a lot of friends and family who loved him dearly . Originally was born in hendon and became a welder, lived in St Patricks Garth  until he married and had children. Theres so much I could tell you about my grandad but I know he hoped that no one would have to suffer like he did battling cancer 
  • I want to give something back to Macmillan as it is an amazing charity 
  • Here are a few facts and statistics; In the UK, more than 13,000 people are diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma each year. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can occur at any age, but your chances of developing the condition increase as you get older, with just over a third of cases diagnosed in people over 75. Slightly more men than women are affected.

  • Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a type of cancer that develops in the lymphatic system, a network of vessels and glands spread throughout your body. The lymphatic system is part of your immune system. Clear fluid called lymph flows through the lymphatic vessels and contains infection-fighting white blood cells known as lymphocytes. In non-Hodgkin lymphoma, the affected lymphocytes start to multiply in an abnormal way and begin to collect in certain parts of the lymphatic system, such as the lymph nodes (glands). The affected lymphocytes lose their infection-fighting properties, making you more vulnerable to infection. The most common symptom of non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a painless swelling in a lymph node, usually in the neck, armpit or groin.

story:
Hello, 

A combination of multiple lockdowns and a busy day job has meant that I haven't managed to cut my hair in over a year. 

As it turns out my circumstances have changed dramatically in that time and I have seen the scale of suffering due to mental illness and the saddening impacts of delayed cancer care. 

In my work as a Jr Dr, I have held the hands of patients weeping from the loneliness of isolation, and from very close family members with beautiful hearts but lost and broken minds. I have seen far too many young and old lives taken by the invisible illness. MIND has been a constant source of guidance and reliance clinically and personally and they do it completely free. 

Secondly, I have found myself disheartened and emotionally flawed on numerous occasions at the injustice of cancer. Patients, where the battle between service provisions and pandemic management has led to delayed diagnosis and/or treatment leading to cancer progression and people who no longer feel whole. Again, this has happened professionally on a daily basis, but it has also happened personally to a strong, courageous woman close to me. Lockdown and chemo has meant no family visits and long days with the only face to face human contact coming from their MacMillan Nurse. Saying that this nurse is a lifeline would be an understatement. 

So, because I need a haircut and because we also need some positivity and a laugh in this time of grey, I am cutting off my locks on Nov 26th. The hair will be going to the Little Princesses Charity so that they can make wigs for our little ones fighting cancer. I am not a natural fundraiser but close friends and colleagues have encouraged me to do this to get some money for vital services which are crippled due to the vast numbers of people who need their help and a huge decrease in funding services. 

Any help you can spare would be greatly appreciated and if you want to part with money please choose either MIND or MacMillan above. I am aiming to raise £250 for each invaluable cause.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives, to this silent killer. My Uncle sadly lost his life from an Acute Heart Attack. 

My mission is to raise money in Vijay Rathour’s honour. He was a courageous man, who's passion was helping others. He made an impact on the lives of everyone he crossed paths with. Furthermore, my aim is to also raise awareness of circulatory disease.  

It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target.

Together we can end the heartbreak caused by heat and circulatory conditions, but we need your help to make this possible. 

 Thanks!

If you would like to make a small donation in his memory to The British Heart Foundation we could help make a difference.

Thank you.

story:
Since May I have been running a virtual Lands' End to John O'Groats every single day - that's 838 miles/1347km! I didn't know if I could do it but on Halloween I will reach 1000km!

I'm asking you to donate £3 to British Heart Foundation - £1 for every 100km I have left to run, more if you can afford it. If 200 of you donate £3 each, then I'll be able to meet my £600 target. I'd be so grateful for your support.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives as a result of cardiovascular disease. I know this because I lost my Dad and Uncles to heart disease and, more recently, my dear friends Stewart and Iain. Every £1 you donate will help save lives. Thank you so much for your support.

story:
On January 21st 2015, age 12, news was given to me and my family that my Father had passed away. I want to raise awareness of this charity and how fundraising can help many more vulnerable people and their families. With more donations, more research and more immediate help, those people suffering with heart problems can get the help they need immediately and not have their families suffer from news like we had. Please take time to read the BHF web page. If you could donate the smallest amount or whatever, it would be much appreciated! 

Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures.

The British Heart Foundation uses its fundraised money to gain research used in hospitals and universities. This research can help those people suffering with heart problems live a longer life that some never got the chance to have.£24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. We can “Beat heartbreak forever”.

Thanks!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm Eve and I'm a Guide Dog.  I was sponsored by lots of lovely people as part of the 'Sponsor a Puppy' scheme in Christmas 2018, and that's how I got my name.  After 2 years of training I'm now a fully-qualified working Guide Dog!  

My mum, family, friends and colleagues are all determined to raise even more to cover my costs over my working life.  I'm going to need food, vet bills, ongoing training and my kit will need keeping up-to-date. They also want to make sure that more people with sight loss can gain their independence through the amazing support provided by my other family at Guide Dogs.

We hope you'll be kind enough to make donations here, but we'll also be setting ourselves some challenges that you can sponsor.  Our first goal is to walk (virtually) from London, via Leeds, to the North Pole in time for  Christmas Eve - that's me!

story:
My name is Peter, I am 89 years old and I live alone. When Lockdown started I decided to exercise by walking around a circuit in the house.
When my daughter in law, Andrea, told me that she was taking up a Club Walking Challenge I thought that I would do the same.
I entered the Wild Atlantic Challenge (a virtual walk along the coast of Donegal which has particular meaning for me as it was where my late wife Angela was born and grew up).  The challenge was to complete 500km within three months starting on 1 June and I completed the challenge in 41 days by walking entirely indoors. The most I have achieved in a day so far is a half marathon - 13.1 miles.

I record my mileage on my iPhone and then Andrea uploads it to Strava on a daily basis - please send me a follow request if you would like to track my progress.

As a continuity project I then set myself the task of completing 1000 miles before my 90th Birthday on 30th December.

The Organiser of the Summer Challenge was very complimentary about my achievement. He was in the process of organising a second Challenge and he asked whether I would be the Ambassador for the Wild Atlantic Winter Challenge which was more ambitious in that participants could choose from four different distances over a period of four months commencing 1 October 2020.

I accepted the position of Ambassador and committed to walk the 500 mile challenge which I am now 1 month underway with.

Prompted by a number of comments and suggestions from friends, this time I am going to walk for a Charity, specifically, CANCER RESEARCH and for the following reasons;
For many years I have carried the memory of my brother and his family.
Early in their marriage they lost a baby son to Cancer of the Bladder.  Later, in her forties, his wife died from Breast Cancer and within a year of retirement he himself died from Cancer of the Bowel. I had the sad experience of sitting next to him in hospital when his Consultant told him that he had two weeks to live.
Currently I have a niece who has recovered from Cancer and I know of two friends who are fighting Cancer. They are not yet confirmed to be in the clear, but one anticipates a return to work in a month’s time after successful treatment undertaken since the beginning of Lockdown.

It seems to me that the Battle against Cancer is being won, if maybe slowly, and additional funding for Research would enable more work to be undertaken.
I started my new Challenge on 1 October.   Would you please consider Sponsoring  me for CANCER RESEARCH on my journey, so that together we may help those who are suffering now and hopefully reduce the spread of this disease in the future.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page and please accept my thanks in anticipation!

story:
Next summer, I will be trekking across the High Atlas Mountains in Morocco with the University of Birmingham. The trek is in aid of Marie Curie - the UK's leading end of life charity, here to support people through all aspects of dying, death and bereavement. During the trek, I will summit the highest peak in North Africa, Mount Toubkal, which stands at 4167m above sea level (half the height of Everest).

Every 5 minutes, someone in the UK dies without getting the care and support they need at the end of their life. Marie Curie fights for a world where everybody gets the best experience they possibly can at the end of their lives. Their nurses, hospices, and support line officers are on the front line to help people, along with their family and friends, through their final years, months, days, and hours of life. Just £20 pays for a Marie Curie Nurse to look after someone with a terminal illness for one hour, in the comfort of their own home.

I have chosen to support Marie Curie because their mission means a lot to me, and the palliative care they provide is especially crucial in these unprecedented times. Any size donation, even just £2, will be hugely appreciated and vital in allowing Marie Curie to continue providing critical end of life support to those who need it.

In memory of Auntie Elaine, Uncle Kevin, Granny O'Doherty and for my mum x

story:
Thank you for taking the time to view our just giving page and listen to our story ...

We are Tegan, Assistant store manager or Launceston Superdrug and Emma, Store manager of Yate Superdrug. We all know that 2020 has been a hard year for many people across the UK, even more so the incredible charities that are there to help everyone when they need it most. Superdrug have supported Marie Curie for a number of years now and as a company we have worked together to raise almost £6,000,000 to help those with the all important end of life care. 

Back in 2015 myself and Emma where two of five lucky Superdrug staff to join a group of fundraisers trek the Great Wall of China, an experience that we certainly will never forget. As a larger group we raised close to £100,000 for Marie Curie which is enough to fund 5000 hours of nursing. While we where there we were fortunate enough to meet an incredible lady called Sara. Sara has been an absolute inspiration and over the years she raised a phenomenal amount of money for Marie Curie. Unfortunately in September 2020 Sara lost her own battle with cancer leaving behind nothing but heart warming stories of fundraising and inspiration to us all. 

In June 2021 myself, Emma and Kara are trekking Snowdon in memory of Sara and we would love to do her proud by raising as much money for Marie Curie as we can. The trek itself begins at night and we will reach the 3560ft summit as the sun rises, the perfect way we feel to honour Sara’s memory. 

We understand that this year has been tough so if you can spare any donation at all we would be incredibly grateful and it would help the fantastic work of the Marie Curie nurses giving the invaluable end of life care, making things just that little bit easier for patients  and their families in their time of need 

Stay say everyone,

Tegan and Emma x

story:
What started out as very casual Sunday Morning bike rides during Lockdown, involving muffin breaks and tonnes of selfies has led us to taking part in a 700mile challenge. 

The 7 of us (Gurjeev, Gurjote, Sandeep, Ravneet, Sukhdev, Harinder & Jasveer) are aiming to cycle 100 miles each throughout the month of November to help raise money and awareness for the WWF. This charity is at the heart of global efforts to address the world’s most important environmental challenges: safeguarding the natural world, tackling climate change and enabling people to use only their fair share of natural resources. 

At present we average about 50miles each a month, so doubling the distance will be a real challenge for us all. In addition to this, the month of November will bring rain, cold and darker evenings - all the more reason to get out and cycle for our beautiful planet. Find us on Strava and be sure to give us a Follow to track our progress

Together we can build a future where people and nature thrive. Your support is much appreciated. Find out more by visiting wwf.org.uk
